author: Ezequiel Minaya
title: U.S. to Offer Guidance on Tax Break for Patents
text:
0 COMMENTS The U.S. Treasury Building in Washington, D.C., U.S. Photo: AP
The Treasury Department will release more guidance by year-end on a tax break for U.S. exporters and other provisions of the new U.S. tax law.
The break, on foreign-derived intangible income, or FDII, cuts the tax U.S. companies owe on royalties from overseas use of intangible assets such as licenses and patents. It reduces the tax rate on such intellectual property to 13.125% through 2025, after which the rate rises to 16.4%. The headline corporate rate is 21%.
The tax break aims to give U.S. taxpayers an incentive to hold patents in the U.S. rather than abroad.
“We know there are a number of issues here,” said Douglas Poms, international tax counsel with the Department of Treasury. “We intend to address them.”
Mr. Poms spoke at the 18th Annual New York University/KPMG Tax Lecture conference in New York City, on Wednesday. He didn’t specify when the guidance would be released or offer much detail on what it would address.
Several panelists said that there was uncertainty surrounding how foreign-derived deduction eligible income is calculated. “We’re looking at that,” Mr. Poms responded.
Some European governments have complained that the FDII tax break amounts to an export subsidy barred under the World Trade Organization’s agreement on subsidies.
The Treasury Department is also expected to release further guidance on other provisions of the tax overhaul, which was signed into law last December.
